title: 107_s991
content: The Act may be cited as the "Andrew Jackson Higgins Gold Medal Act". Andrew Jackson Higgins, born in 1886 in Nebraska, later moved to New Orleans where he founded Higgins Industries in 1930. He designed and produced the "Eureka" boat which evolved into military craft during World War II. Higgins also built assembly line plants for mass production of landing craft vital to the Allied Forces. He took risks by purchasing materials like the 1940 Philippine mahogany crop. During World War II, Higgins Industries, founded by Andrew Jackson Higgins, employed a diverse workforce of up to 30,000 people to produce landing craft for the United States Navy. The company anticipated the need for materials like Philippine mahogany and steel, and ultimately produced 12,300 Landing Craft Vehicle Personnel (LCVP's) for the war effort. During World War II, Higgins Industries employees produced 20,094 boats, including landing craft and Patrol Torpedo boats, and trained 30,000 Navy, Marine, and Coast Guard personnel on the safe operation of landing craft at the Higgins' Boat Operators School. General Dwight D. Eisenhower praised Higgins Industries for providing landing boats essential for conducting campaigns. Higgins landing craft transported troops, tanks, artillery, and mechanized equipment for amphibious operations. Higgins landing craft played a crucial role in amphibious assaults during World War II, including D-day and various other key operations. Captain R.R.M. Emmett praised Andrew Jackson Higgins for his contributions to the war effort. President Dwight D. Eisenhower also acknowledged Higgins' significance in history. President Dwight D. Eisenhower credited Andrew Jackson Higgins for developing the landing craft that played a vital role in winning World War II. Eisenhower stated that without Higgins' landing craft, the strategy of the war would have needed to be completely changed. President Dwight D. Eisenhower credited Andrew Jackson Higgins for developing the landing craft that played a vital role in winning World War II. Without Higgins' landing craft, the strategy of the war would have needed to be completely changed. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. President Eisenhower credited Andrew Jackson Higgins for developing landing craft crucial in WWII. The President is authorized to award a gold medal to Higgins' family and the D-day Museum in New Orleans for their contributions to world peace. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 2 gold medals with emblems and inscriptions for a presentation authorized by the President to honor Andrew Jackson Higgins and the D-day Museum in New Orleans. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medals under this Act at a price covering costs. The medals are considered national medals. An amount not exceeding $60,000 is authorized to pay for the medals, with proceeds from the sale deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.
